name: LAW & SOCIETY

values.comments:
After introducing students to the major theoretical concepts concerning law and society, significant controversial societal issues that deal with law and the legal systems both domestically and internationally will be examined. Class discussions will focus on issues involving civil liberties, the organization of courts, legislatures, the legal profession and administrative agencies. Although the focus will be on law in the United States, law and society in other countries of Africa, Asia, Europe and Latin America will be covered in a comparative context. Readings included research reports, statutes and cases.

Students had very mixed opinions on this course. Some described it as “enjoyable” with “dynamic discussion” whereby they “learned quite a bit.” The other half of the reviewers had negative responses, with the consensus being, “not enough class participation — just [the] professor talking at the students about his opinions.”

Several students had strong negative reactions to Professor Fetni. More than one complained of his strong “liberal bias” and another described him as “rude and condescending.” Students mostly seemed to agree that much of Fetni’s lecturing was simply him delivering his own political views. Still, some students did like the professor, praising his enthusiasm and describing him as “easygoing.”

The workload for the course seemed acceptable, as there was reportedly a “manageable amount of reading.” However, a student did complain about the specificity of the exam questions, claiming one would need a “photographic memory” to answer some of them. Fetni also apparently included material on his exams not found in the book. This class is open to all classes and has no prerequisites. *This review is based on the 7 student comments that were submitted.
